title: Rufus Daggett
text:
Rufus Daggett (October 6, 1837 – February 9, 1912) was a <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> officer during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. On February 18, 1865, <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> nominated Daggett for appointment to the grade of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29%23American%20Civil%20War">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers, to rank from January 15, 1865, and the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> confirmed the appointment on March 3, 1865.
Born in New Berlin, New York on October 6, 1837, Daggett first served in the Union Army as a <a href="First%20lieutenant%20%28United%20States%29">first lieutenant</a> with the <a href="14th%20New%20York%20Volunteer%20Infantry%20Regiment">14th New York Volunteer Infantry Regiment</a> from May 17, 1861 until he was mustered out of the volunteers on December 4, 1861. He returned to the army and was appointed <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a>, August 20, 1862, <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a>, September 5, 1863, and <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a>, August 12, 1864, of the <a href="117th%20New%20York%20Volunteer%20Infantry">117th New York Volunteer Infantry</a> Regiment. He commanded a brigade in the <a href="Army%20of%20the%20James">Army of the James</a> from September 17, 1864 to September 29, 1864 when he was wounded in fighting at Fort Gilmer, Virginia during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Chaffin%27s%20Farm">Battle of Chaffin's Farm and New Market Heights</a>. He returned to service as a brevet brigadier general to lead brigades in the <a href="XXIV%20Corps%20%28Union%20Army%29">XXIV Corps (Union Army)</a> from January 15, 1865 to March 13, 1865 and the <a href="X%20Corps%20%28Union%20Army%29">X Corps (Union Army)</a> in the <a href="Department%20of%20North%20Carolina">Department of North Carolina</a> from March 27, 1865 to May 13, 1865 and a division in the X Corps from May 13, 1865 to June 8, 1865 when he was mustered out of the volunteers.
After the war, he ran a clothing business and later a hardware store. In 1900, he returned to Utica and was appointed postmaster. He had been a Republican.
Rufus Daggett died February 12, 1912 at Utica, New York. He was interred at New Forest Cemetery in Utica.
